required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

collaborator.agency: The Danish Dairy Research Foundation, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: Investigators will test the long-term health effects of eating a dairy-based protein-rich breakfast and/or performing regular physical training for 12 weeks in 100 previous 'breakfast skipping' young overweight women (2 x 2 factorial design). Measurements of body composition, physical fitness, metabolic health parameters, faeces (microbiota activity and composition), satiety and daily energy intake will be collected.

detailed_description.textblock:
Overweight is a global health challenge, which for many starts in early life and accumulate health problems throughout life. A meta-analysis has shown that overweight adolescents are more likely to develop severe obesity compared to normal-weight adolescents (Brown 2013; Santesso 2012). Therefore, simple life-style strategies targeting adolescents are needed to prevent further weight gain, improve body composition and overall health profile, which will benefit both the individual and the health care system.
One out of four young Danish women (16-24 yrs) are overweight or obese (Bendtsen 2013). Epidemiological studies suggest that the probability of being normal weight seems greater when eating breakfast (Santesso 2012), but approx. 1/3 of Danish young women do not eat breakfast regularly (Kr√∏lner 2018). Protein-rich meals provide greater satiety compared to protein-poor meals despite the same energy content (Paddon-Jones 2014; Leidy 2013; Leidy 2015). A high calcium intake also seems to have a positive effect on weight regulation (Lorenzen 2011) just as fermented milk products positively affect the gut microflora (Kok 2018).
Hypothesis: A fermented milk product such as 'skyr' for breakfast will have a beneficial effect on weight control by virtue of high protein, calcium and probiotic lactic acid bacteria.
Aim: to investigate effects of eating 'skyr' for breakfast alone and combined with regular training on body composition and health related parameters in young overweight women.

secondary_outcome.description: blood sample measurement of fasting glucose
Blood sample measurement of fasting insulin
Oral glucose tolerance test measured as the area under the curve
weight measurement in kg, height in meters

intervention.description: Participants must consume 300 g of dairy product (equalling 30 g protein)
Participants must perform exercise training 3 times per week.
Participants are not allowed to train

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- BMI >25
Exclusion Criteria:
- smoking
- illness and use of medication affecting the study outcomes
- allergy towards milk and yoghurt
- weightloss/gain >5kg the last 6 months
- dieting
- eating disorder
- pregnancy
- breast feeding
- unable to speak and understand danish

facility.name: Aarhus University, Department for Public Health, Section for Sport Science
